Author: AZA43
Title: Your Laptop Could Soon Get 10 Times Its Current Battery Life
Content: Stanford researchers have come up with a way to pack 10 times the electricity into laptop batteries using silicon nanowires.

Author: socalsamba
Title: Saving Your Company From The Deadpool

Author: whacked_new
Content:
"a. there's a generation that has absolutely no patience for the interfaces you and I love."

It's been over half a year since I last visited IILWY... this time it almost gave me a seizure. I'm amazed that at age 23 I have already hit a complete generation gap.

Author: qaexl
Content:
That's a very interesting reaction. I find it interesting that a lot of people get suspicious over a 'good thing'. Part of the culture, I guess.

I've been hearing about Google investing into alternative energy projects, including Nanosolar and a (non-torrodial) fusion group that was formerly funded by the government. I've been hearing these rumors for the past two years or so. I heard about the Nanosolar bit right when Google was building all those datacenters, including the one in Washington (or Oregon?) near that huge power plant. I had also heard that Sergey Brin, Larry Page, and Page's brother, Carl Page funded Nanosolar. You know, right after the Google IPO and Carl Page sold his company to Yahoo. (Though they supposedly invested a few years before the payday, so ... ).

All of this is hearsay, of course. http://www.treehugger.com/files/2005/06/google_founders.php

Here's the bottom line. Nanosolar has hungry customers beating down their door. Like the NYTimes article says, why should they be making a big media fuss right now? Why do they need to prove to the world about those figures? It actually reminds me pre-IPO Google.com. "Come see for yourself."

Author: qaexl
Content: Not so. With California getting ready to give government subsidies for solar-generated power, Nanosolar's customers are right there. They might even have gotten subsidies and tax incentives for locating their factory there. There may also be logistics issues because they are not using silicon.
